questions.prompt: Parseval's theorem states that the average power of a periodic signal equals:
questions.explanation: P_avg = Σ_{k=-∞}^{∞} |X_k|². Each term |X_k|² is the power contribution of the k-th harmonic. The total power is the sum of all harmonic powers.

questions.prompt: The average power of a periodic signal in the time domain is defined as:
questions.explanation: P_avg = (1/T₀)∫_{T₀}|x(t)|² dt. This integrates the instantaneous power |x(t)|² over one period and normalises by T₀. For complex signals, |x(t)|² = x(t)·x*(t).

questions.prompt: In the Parseval's theorem derivation, which property is crucial?
options: B) Orthogonality of FS basis functions
questions.explanation: Through the derivation, substituting the FS for x(t) and x*(t), the cross-terms vanish due to orthogonality (only k=m terms survive). This is why Parseval's is sometimes called a consequence of orthogonality.

questions.prompt: For a real periodic signal, the power can be written as:
questions.explanation: For real signals, |X_{-k}| = |X_k|. So the sum from -∞ to +∞ can be written as |X₀|² (the DC term once) plus 2·Σ|X_k|² for k=1 to ∞ (positive and negative k pairs).

options: A) The phase of the k-th harmonic
B) The power contribution of the k-th harmonic
C) The energy of the signal
questions.explanation: |X_k|² is the power spectral component at harmonic k. It tells you how much power the k-th harmonic contributes to the total signal power.

questions.prompt: A square pulse train with X₀ = 0.5 and the first 3 pairs have |X_k|² = 0.1, 0.05, 0.02. Approximate total power in the first 3 harmonics:
questions.explanation: P ≈ |X₀|² + 2(|X₁|² + |X₂|² + |X₃|²) = 0.25 + 2(0.17) = 0.25 + 0.34 = 0.59. DC power plus twice each positive-k power (for the negative-k pair).

questions.prompt: Parseval's theorem can be used as a sanity check because:
options: A) It only works for square waves
B) If time-domain and frequency-domain power disagree, you have an error in your FS
C) It gives the exact signal shape
questions.explanation: Both sides must give the same number. If you compute P from the time integral and from Σ|X_k|² and they don't match, your FS coefficients are wrong. This is a powerful verification tool.

questions.prompt: Why are periodic signals called 'power signals'?
options: A) They have finite power but infinite energy
B) They have finite energy and finite power
questions.explanation: A periodic signal extends to ±∞, so its total energy is infinite. But the average power per period (P_avg = (1/T₀)∫|x|²dt) is finite. Hence: power signals.

questions.prompt: If 10 harmonics capture 95% of total power and 20 harmonics capture 99%, the essential bandwidth is closer to:
options: C) Depends on the accuracy requirement
questions.explanation: Essential bandwidth depends on how much power is 'enough'. For 95% capture, ~10 harmonics suffice (bandwidth ≈ 10ω₀). For 99%, you need ~20 (bandwidth ≈ 20ω₀). The choice depends on the application.

questions.prompt: In the derivation of Parseval's theorem, the integral ∫x(t)e^{jkω₀t}dt/(T₀) equals:
questions.explanation: The analysis equation is X_k = (1/T₀)∫x(t)e^{−jkω₀t}dt. With the positive exponent (+jk), we get (1/T₀)∫x*(t)e^{jkω₀t}dt = X_k* — the conjugate. This is a key step in the Parseval's derivation.
